cell.html: An activist who helped pass the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 . A bout of polio at age 18 left him requiring a wheelchair. [29]
cell.text: An activist who helped pass the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 . A bout of polio at age 18 left him requiring a wheelchair. [29]

cell.html: A crusader for equality of disabled people, Ducharme contracted polio in 1953. The disease left her a quadriplegic and dependent on a respirator for the rest of her life. [30]
cell.text: A crusader for equality of disabled people, Ducharme contracted polio in 1953. The disease left her a quadriplegic and dependent on a respirator for the rest of her life. [30]

cell.html: Author and disability rights advocate, Hugh Gallagher contracted polio at college and subsequently required a wheelchair due to lower-body paralysis. He aided the drafting of the Architectural Barriers Act of 1968 . [31]
cell.text: Author and disability rights advocate, Hugh Gallagher contracted polio at college and subsequently required a wheelchair due to lower-body paralysis. He aided the drafting of the Architectural Barriers Act of 1968 . [31]

cell.html: Heumann caught polio when she was 18 months old, and is unable to walk. She went on to become a disability rights activist, co-founding the World Institute on Disability , and served as Assistant Secretary for Special Education and Rehabilitative Services during the Clinton Administration . [32]
cell.text: Heumann caught polio when she was 18 months old, and is unable to walk. She went on to become a disability rights activist, co-founding the World Institute on Disability , and served as Assistant Secretary for Special Education and Rehabilitative Services during the Clinton Administration . [32]

cell.html: A disability rights activist who co-founded the World Institute on Disability and was the first severely disabled student to attend the University of California, Berkeley . At age 14 Roberts contracted polio; he was paralysed and in an iron lung within 24 hours. When told he would be a vegetable for the rest of his life, he "decided to be an artichoke...a little prickly on the outside but with a big heart." [33]
cell.text: A disability rights activist who co-founded the World Institute on Disability and was the first severely disabled student to attend the University of California, Berkeley . At age 14 Roberts contracted polio; he was paralysed and in an iron lung within 24 hours. When told he would be a vegetable for the rest of his life, he "decided to be an artichoke...a little prickly on the outside but with a big heart." [33]

context.text: List of poliomyelitis survivors - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Judith Heumann had to take legal action to be allowed to become a teacher.
[ edit ] Mistakenly believed to have survived polio
Toymaker Margarete Steiff was paralysed as an infant.
Director Francis Ford Coppola 's childhood was interrupted by polio for over a year.
Actors Donald Sutherland (above) and Alan Alda both played the role of Hawkeye Pierce and both had polio as children.

This is an incomplete list , which may never be able to satisfy certain standards for completeness. Revisions and sourced additions are welcome. Itzhak Perlman , a polio survivor, plays the violin sitting down.
Actress Marion Davies caught polio as an adult.
Television presenter David Onley found his employers to be supportive in accommodating his extra needs.
This categorised alphabetical list contains only those people with a firm and uncontested diagnosis made while still alive.

entity.htmlSnippet:
NameLifeComments
Justin Whitlock Dart, Jr.1930–2002An activist who helped pass the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. A bout of polio at age 18 left him requiring a wheelchair.[29]
Theresa Ducharme1945–2004A crusader for equality of disabled people, Ducharme contracted polio in 1953. The disease left her a quadriplegic and dependent on a respirator for the rest of her life.[30]
Hugh Gallagher1933–2004Author and disability rights advocate, Hugh Gallagher contracted polio at college and subsequently required a wheelchair due to lower-body paralysis. He aided the drafting of the Architectural Barriers Act of 1968.[31]
Judith Heumannborn 1947Heumann caught polio when she was 18 months old, and is unable to walk. She went on to become a disability rights activist, co-founding the World Institute on Disability, and served as Assistant Secretary for Special Education and Rehabilitative Services during the Clinton Administration.[32]
Ed Roberts1939–1995A disability rights activist who co-founded the World Institute on Disability and was the first severely disabled student to attend the University of California, Berkeley. At age 14 Roberts contracted polio; he was paralysed and in an iron lung within 24 hours. When told he would be a vegetable for the rest of his life, he "decided to be an artichoke...a little prickly on the outside but with a big heart."[33]
